statement: As someone who cares a lot about keeping our community clean and welcoming, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility, clear rules, and real consequences for breaking them. We should have plenty of trash and recycling bins in busy public areas, but also enforce fines for littering so people understand there are costs to disrespecting shared spaces. I’d also like to see more community clean-up events through churches and local groups, so folks feel pride and ownership in their neighborhoods. When people feel connected to a place—and know the rules are enforced—they’re much less likely to treat it like a dumping ground.

statement: At my age, I’ve seen how a bit of care—or neglect—can change a neighborhood, and litter is one of those small things that makes a big difference in how people feel about a place. The best policies mix practical steps—plenty of bins, regular clean-up crews, deposits on bottles and cans—with education in schools and community campaigns that make keeping our streets clean a shared value, not just a rule. I’d also support fines for repeat offenders, but paired with community service so people have to help clean the very spaces they’ve disrespected. When everyone feels some ownership of our parks and sidewalks, from the children to the retirees like me, littering becomes socially unacceptable, not just illegal.

statement: I think the best way to stop littering is to have more trash and recycling bins everywhere and make it super easy to use them. Schools and communities should also teach kids from a young age why littering hurts animals, the environment, and even how our neighborhoods look and feel. There should be clear fines or consequences for people who still litter on purpose, because it’s not fair for everyone else who cares and tries to keep public spaces clean.
